headline: Stocks are rallying again. Are they out of the woods?

headline: Big Tech earnings can make or break this market

headline: Deutsche Bank shares surge as it promises more cash for investors

headline: ‘Fundamental rethink:’ Investors dump China shares despite new efforts to shore up the economy
body: Investors have been dumping Chinese stocks at an unprecedented pace, exiting the world’s second largest economy despite efforts by Beijing to juice growth by borrowing more to fund extra spending.

headline: Why bitcoin is surging again
body: Bitcoin is rocketing higher, topping $35,000 for the first time since May 2022. It’s up 20% over the past five days.

headline: Microsoft, Google post strong quarterly sales growth as Big Tech continues its comeback
body: Big tech companies are continuing a turnaround from last year, as Alphabet, Microsoft and Snap kicked off earnings season with strong sales results for the quarter ended in September.

headline: Shares in one of London’s biggest IPOs this year have crashed 82%
body: Three months ago, CAB Payments stumbled when it went public on the London Stock Exchange, its shares falling nearly 10% on their first day of trading on a market that has been starved recently of new listings.

headline: The Fed is losing control
body: America’s first inflation crisis in decades, combined with the Federal Reserve’s aggressive interest rate hikes to combat it, has made for a topsy-turvy past couple years on Main Street and Wall Street alike. It has weighed on consumers and kept investors constantly second-guessing themselves.

headline: ESG investing is dying on Wall Street. Here’s why
body: The market for environmental, social and corporate governance, or ESG, investing is fundamentally broken.

headline: A key market indicator hasn’t been this high since the Great Recession
body: For a while now the theme of “higher for longer” has dominated market speak – that’s the idea that the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates elevated for a prolonged period of time to bring inflation down.

headline: Mortgage rates advance toward 8%
body: Mortgage rates continued to climb last week amid a stronger than expected economy.

headline: Tesla third-quarter earnings slow, missing forecasts
body: Tesla reported a drop in third-quarter earnings as the electric vehicle maker fell short of Wall Street expectations.

headline: What the Israel-Hamas war means for defense stocks
body: When war breaks out, defense companies tend to make money. That means aerospace and defense stocks tend to rise during geopolitical unrest.

headline: Goldman Sachs CEO stops doing controversial DJ gigs
body: Goldman Sachs chief executive (and noted party DJ) David Solomon will no longer perform at high-profile events, picking Wall Street over South Beach, a representative from the second-largest investment bank confirmed to CNN.

headline: What the Israel-Hamas war means for US markets
body: Growing unrest in the Middle East has cast a shadow on global financial markets.

headline: Jamie Dimon warns: ‘Now may be the most dangerous time the world has seen in decades’
body: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon kicked off third-quarter earnings season Friday with a stern warning to investors: “Now may be the most dangerous time the world has seen in decades,” he wrote in the company’s report.

headline: Investors flock to defensive stocks and safe havens on worries about Israel-Hamas war
body: The Israel-Hamas war is sending investors in search of defensive assets.

body: Oil prices surged and the Israeli currency fell at the start of the week as investors reacted to war between Hamas and Israel.

body: Jaime Gilinski Bacal, a Colombian banking and real estate entrepreneur, has taken control of Metro Bank as part of a bigger rescue deal to fill a hole in the UK lender’s finances.

headline: Jobs report shock: American economy added a stunning 336,000 jobs in September
body: US markets chewed over the latest jobs report showed the economy added a whopping 336,000 positions last month. While that’s better than August’s tepid figures, it’s not exactly the cooling labor market Fed Chair Jerome Powell is looking for to keep inflation in check.

headline: Proceed with caution before looking at your 401(k)
body: October is known to be a spooky month and stocks don’t have a good track record of getting spared.

headline: Levi Strauss cuts annual forecasts as promotions, wholesale weakness weigh

body: Shares in UK lender Metro Bank sank as much as 31% Thursday following a report that it was urgently seeking to raise funds to shore up its finances.

headline: Why Wall Street investors are freaking out
body: October has a long history of spooking Wall Street, and this week’s market action is serving up a particular dose of terror for traders.

headline: SoftBank CEO says artificial general intelligence will come within 10 years
body: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son said he believes artificial general intelligence (AGI), artificial intelligence that surpasses human intelligence in almost all areas, will be realized within 10 years.

headline: Dow sinks by more than 400 points as spiking yields weigh on stocks

body: Former President Donald Trump showed up to the opening day of the $250 million civil fraud trial against him, his eldest sons, their companies and Trump Organization executives in Manhattan on Monday.

headline: Tesla sales slow, missing Wall Street forecasts

headline: London is suffering an office ‘recession.’ Meta just paid $181 million to dump a lease

body: The largest public offering since 2021 is here.

headline: The European Central Bank takes rates to a record high and signals the end of hikes
body: The European Central Bank raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to 4% Thursday and hinted it was done with its protracted campaign of rate hikes to tame stubborn inflation.

headline: Wall Street’s mood is improving — but it’s far from upbeat
body: Wall Street’s optimism has edged up in recent weeks after an August slump to levels not seen since the collapse of several regional banks earlier this year.

headline: Birkenstock heads for Wall Street in another blow to Europe
body: German shoemaker Birkenstock has filed for an initial public offering in New York, becoming the latest European company to choose the United States as the place to raise money on the stock market.

headline: CEOs are having their worst year in decades
body: It’s been a bad year for CEOs.

headline: This week’s US inflation data is very important. Here’s why
body: Markets hate uncertainty, and there’s a lot of it this fall: The United Auto Workers union may strike on Friday, the federal government is heading toward another potential shutdown in October, geopolitical tensions with China remain heightened and oil prices could stay elevated through December. There’s also the looming question about whether the Federal Reserve will hike interest rates again.

body: Google will face off in court Tuesday against government officials who accuse the company of antitrust violations in its massive search business, kicking off a long-anticipated showdown that could reshape one of the internet’s most dominant platforms.

headline: The case for owning stocks over bonds is crumbling
body: The allure of owning stocks over less risky investments is at its lowest level in decades, according to one measure, despite the equity market’s race upward this year.

headline: Norway’s $1.4 trillion investment fund is shutting its China office
body: Norges Bank Investment Management (NBIM), which operates the world’s largest sovereign wealth fund, has started the process of closing down its office in Shanghai, in another sign of big global companies pulling back operations in the world’s second largest economy.

headline: Why stocks could avoid a steep selloff this September
body: US stocks typically see their worst performance of the year in September, but there are signs the market could avoid a steep downturn this time around.

But the Fed hasn’t ruled out additional rate increases, and that could still happen unless inflation slows further.

body: The US economy added 187,000 jobs last month, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Wall Street ended the day mostly higher, on hopes that the Federal Reserve would soon end its rate-hiking campaign.

headline: Why Wall Street’s obsession with a company you probably never heard of is sending stocks surging

body: The artificial intelligence boom continues to fuel a blockbuster year for chipmaker Nvidia.

headline: Why stock investors are suddenly so scared
body: Many investors are running a sizable profit this year – the S&P 500 is about 14% higher in 2023. But market losses have been piling up over the past month, particularly on growing fears of contagion from an economic slowdown in China. Inflation, Russia’s war in Ukraine and weakness in America’s banks also have Wall Street spooked.

headline: China’s ‘Lehman moment?’ Big investment firm misses payments

headline: Mortgage rates soar to their highest level in 21 years
body: US mortgage rates surged this week, rising to their highest level in 21 years.

headline: What are ‘Big Short’ Michael Burry and Warren Buffett seeing that we aren’t?

body: Esmark Inc. announced an all-cash public offer for US Steel for $35 per share on Monday. The offer comes hours after news that rival Cleveland-Cliffs was in talks to purchase of US Steel. Shares of US Steel surged double-digits on Monday.

headline: Does it matter to stocks whether the Federal Reserve hikes or pauses rates in September?

headline: Wall Street digests the jobs report, credit downgrade and more earnings
body: US markets tumbled Friday after absorbing the latest jobs report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The US economy added 187,000 jobs in July, and the unemployment rate ticked down to 3.5% — a “Goldilocks” report that is neither good nor bad.

headline: Judge narrows Trump-era Google antitrust case brought by states and the Justice Department

headline: US investors are searching overseas for opportunities

headline: Americans are ‘unwittingly funding’ blacklisted Chinese companies, Congressional panel says

headline: The winning numbers for the $940 million Mega Millions jackpot have been drawn

headline: Tupperware shares are up 165% this week as meme stock mania takes hold

body: US mortgage rates moved higher this week following the Federal Reserve’s rate hike, after dropping last week.

headline: Wall Street suddenly appears confident America will avoid a recession

headline: Shell and TotalEnergies profits cut in half by lower oil prices

headline: The stock market is dominated by just a handful of companies. The Biden administration is worried

headline: How stock market expectations have changed this year

headline: What’s ahead this week for Wall Street and the economy

headline: AI investment is booming. How much is hype?

headline: Markets and consumers are in an upbeat mood. Here’s why

headline: US startups are having a bad year. Relief isn’t coming

headline: On Wall Street, these are unprecedented times

headline: The bond and stock markets might finally agree on Fed expectations
body: The bond and stock markets are finally seeing eye to eye when it comes to the Federal Reserve.

headline: Jamie Dimon and other Wall Street titans say the US economy is strong for now, but warn about the future
body: The nation’s biggest banks reported robust second-quarter earnings on Friday, marking an auspicious start to the season.

headline: The Nasdaq-100 index is getting a makeover
body: The Nasdaq-100 index is getting a fresh look.

headline: Another earnings season begins, but investors are already looking beyond it
body: As the second-quarter earnings season kicks off this week, investors want answers on the health of the United States’ companies and its economy.

headline: The latest on markets and the lower-than-expected job numbers
body: After white-hot jobs data pushed markets into the red on Thursday, traders were mostly unmoved by the latest monthly jobs report from the Labor Department released on Friday. Follow the latest news here.

headline: Some investors are shunning Wall Street’s tech frenzy
body: While many on Wall Street have chased the monster rally in mega-cap tech stocks this year, exchange-traded fund (ETF) investors seem to be bucking the “all-in on tech stocks” trend and opting for a more diversified strategy.

headline: Dow tumbles on red-hot US job market
body: Stocks tumbled on Thursday after fresh data signaled that the labor market remains piping hot, heightening concerns that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates for longer than expected.

headline: Hong Kong stocks slump on worries about Chinese banks, US interest rates
body: Hong Kong stocks on Thursday recorded their worst day in four months, after Goldman Sachs downgraded major Chinese banks on local government debt risks and the US Federal Reserve gave a hawkish outlook.

headline: Tesla shares rise on strong sales report
body: Tesla shares shot up 5% Monday after it reported stronger-than-expected quarterly sales. Tesla’s stock is building on an already strong run this year.

headline: Apple is now worth $3 trillion, boosted by the Nasdaq’s best start in 40 years
body: Apple’s stock ended trading Friday valued at $3 trillion, the only company ever to reach that milestone. It has been riding a Big Tech stock wave that has given the Nasdaq its best first half gain in 40 years.

headline: Why Wall Street is bullish on beaten-down energy stocks
body: Some investors are turning bullish on energy stocks, despite their disappointing performance this year and some major challenges facing Big Oil.

headline: Prosecutors charge three investors with insider trading in Trump SPAC deal
body: Federal prosecutors arrested three investors on Thursday on insider trading charges related to a deal to take former President Donald Trump’s media business public.

headline: Mortgage rates jump higher: 30-year fixed rises to 6.7%
body: The housing market showed clear signs of slowing, according to new data released on Thursday.

headline: Why it might be time to get optimistic about the stock market
body: It’s hard to remain cheery as economic conditions go soft, stocks bounce around with whiplash-inducing volatility and inflation remains stickier than superglue.

headline: American companies are draining their cash at the dumbest possible time
body: Companies are sitting on a lot less cash than they were last year, largely because they’re spending it on share buybacks and corporate dividends.

headline: India’s stock market is hitting record highs. Here’s why
body: India’s stock market is booming as investors take a chance on one of the few bright spots in a fragile global economy.

headline: US home prices continued to rebound in April
body: Home prices rose in April for a third consecutive month, according to the latest S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller US National Home Price Index released Tuesday.

headline: New home sales surged 20% in May from a year ago
body: New home sales surged in May, as buyers looked to new construction as an alternative to the low inventory of existing homes for sale.

headline: Are investors ignoring the Federal Reserve’s warning?
body: Stocks fell last week as several signs pointed to the Federal Reserve continuing to hike rates this year.

headline: Bitcoin hits its highest level in a year
body: Bitcoin on Friday shot up to its highest level in about a year. The cryptocurrency rose above $31,400 a coin on Friday, its highest level since 2022, before paring back its gains.

headline: FDIC accidentally reveals details about Silicon Valley Bank’s biggest customers
body: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. mistakenly revealed to Bloomberg News details on the biggest customers at Silicon Valley Bank, the failed bank whose depositors were rescued by through emergency action by regulators.

headline: JPMorgan fined $4 million for deleting 47 million emails including some requested in subpoenas
body: The Securities and Exchange Commission fined JPMorgan Chase $4 million for mistakenly deleting 47 million emails, many of which the regulator was trying to access as part of multiple probes.

headline: Small stocks are cheap and finally joining the market rally
body: Beaten-down stocks of smaller companies are finally making a comeback, underscoring Wall Street’s newfound optimism.

headline: Global markets slide as recession fears grip investors
body: Stock markets in Europe and Asia fell Friday as investors became increasingly worried that more interest rate hikes by central banks would tip major economies into a prolonged recession.

headline: Central banks to Wall Street: More pain is coming
body: Market euphoria in early June, spurred on by a pause in interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, is well behind us now. Central Bank leaders in the US and across the globe delivered a clear message to markets this week: We’re not done hiking.

headline: The latest market news as traders digest latest economic data and Fed Chair Powell’s testimony
body: Traders are parsing a slew of economic data, along with comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell after he delivered a second day of congressional testimony.

headline: Mortgage rates tick down for the third week in a row
body: Mortgage rates ticked lower for the third week in a row as investors absorbed strong signals from the housing industry and last week’s pause on rate hikes by the Federal Reserve after 10 consecutive hikes.

headline: Germany’s biggest newspaper is cutting 20% of jobs as it prepares for an AI-powered digital future
body: German tabloid newspaper Bild plans to cut hundreds of jobs as it scales back its regional operations this year — and ramps up its use of artificial intelligence in preparation for a digital-only future.

headline: The largest newspaper publisher in the US sues Google, alleging online ad monopoly
body: Gannett, the largest newspaper publisher in the United States, is suing Google, alleging the tech giant holds a monopoly over the digital ad market.

headline: Warren Buffett pours more money into Japan’s stock market
body: Billionaire investor Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway has added to its holdings in Japan’s five biggest trading houses, likely underpinning strong momentum propelling the nation’s stock market to multi-year highs.

headline: Bull market or fool’s market? Investors say it’s likely the latter
body: The stock market has made incredible strides since its downturn last year – so much so, it’s difficult to believe the economy could be on the verge of recession.

headline: Micron invests another $600 million in China despite partial sales ban
body: Micron said Friday it was committed to China and would invest 4.3 billion yuan ($603 million) over the next few years in its chip packaging facility in the city of Xian.

headline: Mortgage rates tick down for the second week in a row
body: Mortgage rates ticked down this week for the second week in a row, as investors absorbed the Federal Reserve’s expected pause on raising the federal funds rate after 10 consecutive rate hikes.

headline: European Central Bank hikes interest rates to highest level in 22 years
body: The European Central Bank raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point Thursday and signaled another hike to come next month, unmoved by evidence of a mild recession in the 20 countries that use the euro.

headline: June 14, 2023 Fed interest rate and stock market news
body: The Federal Reserve said Wednesday it has decided to pause its rate-hiking campaign for now.

headline: Larry Ellison edges past Bill Gates as world’s fourth-richest person, Bloomberg says
body: Oracle founder Larry Ellison is reaping the benefits of artificial intelligence popularity, edging past Microsoft founder Bill Gates to land the number four spot on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index on Monday, according to Bloomberg.

headline: ‘Bumps and pain’ coming for the US economy, says Goldman Sachs CEO
body: The US economy has been surprisingly resilient this year, but painful bumps are likely coming, said Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon in an interview with CNBC on Monday morning.

headline: Here’s how Italy’s Silvio Berlusconi made his billions
body: Silvio Berlusconi, the billionaire former prime minister of Italy, died Monday, leaving behind a sprawling business empire.

headline: The AI boom is here. Is it too late to invest?
body: Wall Street has a lot to worry about – recession and war in Europe, interest rate hikes, sticky inflation, and a softening US economy. But there’s at least one sector of market euphoria keeping investors optimistic: artificial intelligence.

headline: Goldman Sachs cuts oil price forecast by almost 10%
body: Goldman Sachs has slashed its forecast for oil prices by nearly 10%, citing weak demand in China and a glut of supply from sanctioned countries, including Russia.

headline: The Fed meets this week. What can investors expect?
body: Stocks have just come off a seemingly auspicious week — but could the Federal Reserve’s June meeting dampen the rally?

headline: How can we possibly be in a bull market right now? Two letters: AI
body: The Eurozone has sunk into recession and economists worry that the United States is next. We’re worrying about rate hikes, inflation, lower spending, layoffs, surging mortgage costs and a war in Europe. So what explains a bull market in a bear economy? Artificial intelligence.

headline: America has lost half its public companies since the 1990s. Here’s why
body: The S&P 500 officially entered a bull market on Thursday, gaining 20% off of its October lows. But those gains came from just a few tech and AI companies with mega-cap stocks soaring higher. Cyclical and smaller companies are still largely suffering.

headline: It’s official. We’re in a bull market
body: Wall Street is feeling bullish again.

headline: Americans’ wealth rises by $3 trillion but remains below early 2022 peak
body: Elevated by a strong stock market, Americans’ household wealth rose to nearly $149 trillion in the first quarter of 2023, new federal data shows. But that’s still several trillion dollars shy of its recent peak.

headline: Mortgage rates fall for the first time in three weeks
body: Mortgage rates dropped this week after a three-week climb, as rates remain volatile amid conflicting economic indicators.

headline: They said we were getting a recession. Instead, we’re getting a bull market
body: What do you get when you mix recession fears, interest rate hikes, a spending slowdown and a housing crunch? A recipe for a bull market, apparently.

headline: SEC sues Coinbase for allegedly acting as an unregistered crypto broker
body: The US Securities and Exchange Commission, Wall Street’s top regulator, sued Coinbase, America’s largest crypto exchange, on Tuesday. The SEC is cracking down on some of the biggest names in cryptocurrency over alleged security violations.

headline: Main Street traders are taking big risks. They might not pay off
body: “Sell in May and go away” — shorthand for the idea that US stocks rise more between November and April than over the summer — is one of the most oft-repeated adages on Wall Street.

headline: Binance hit by outflows of $790 million in last 24 hours, data shows
body: Investors have pulled around $790 million from the crypto exchange Binance and its US affiliate in the last 24 hours, data firm Nansen said Tuesday, a day after a top US regulator sued both exchanges.

headline: The S&P 500 finally broke through a key level. Now what?
body: The S&P 500 index on Friday closed at its highest level in almost a year. But that doesn’t mean that stocks are poised for a bull run just yet.

headline: Dow surges over 700 points as investors cheer jobs report and debt ceiling deal
body: The Dow surged over 700 points mid-afternoon Friday as investors applauded Congress’s passage of the debt ceiling deal and celebrated a cheerful jobs report.

headline: Here’s the real reason Target’s stock is dropping
body: If you follow right-wing media or Twitter, you may have seen a lot of coverage recently about Target’s stock price falling. It’s not because of recent LGBTQ backlash, though.

headline: Hong Kong leads global market rally with best day in three months
body: Global stocks climbed Friday, led by a resurgent Hong Kong market, as investors greeted signs that the US Federal Reserve may hold off raising interest rates this month, the end of the US debt ceiling drama, and talk that China might unveil new measures to boost its faltering economic recovery.

headline: The uber-wealthy are doing just fine and Wall Street is cashing in
body: Worries of a possible global recession are deepening as heightened inflation and interest rates act as a brake on spending, while geopolitical strife adds to a sense of profound economic uncertainty.

headline: China’s small and medium-sized factories post surprise growth, easing market anxiety
body: A key gauge of China’s small- and medium-sized factories showed their surprise return to expansion last month, which eased market anxiety about growth stalling in the world’s second largest economy.

headline: From Elon Musk to Jamie Dimon, CEOs flock to China as risks to trade and investment rise
body: The CEOs of some of America’s biggest companies are in China this week to take the pulse of one of their top markets after the country reopened following nearly three years of pandemic restrictions.

headline: Fueled by AI, Nvidia joins the $1 trillion club
body: Booming demand for its AI chips has landed Nvidia a prime spot in one of the most exclusive clubs on Wall Street: The chipmaker hit a market cap of $1 trillion on Tuesday.

headline: US home prices rose in March for the second month in a row
body: US home prices rose slightly in March, showing a continuing recovery, according to the latest S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller US National Home Price Index, released Tuesday.

headline: Global market cheers for US debt ceiling deal fade
body: European stocks and oil prices gave up early gains Monday, but US stock futures stayed positive following weekend news of an agreement that could avert a catastrophic US debt default.

headline: Josef Newgarden wins thrilling Indy 500
body: Josef Newgarden has won the 2023 Indy 500 in a wild finish after three crashes in the last 16 laps. He held off Marcus Ericsson in the final lap.

headline: Why does Wall Street expect a rate hike in June?
body: Wall Street expects the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in June. Not only that, it finally believes the central bank when it says it likely won’t cut rates this year.

headline: JPMorgan is cutting about 500 jobs
body: JPMorgan Chase is letting go of about 500 employees this week across the bank, a spokesperson confirmed to CNN on Friday.

headline: World’s biggest investment fund takes on Exxon and Chevron over the climate crisis
body: The world’s biggest investor in the stock market wants ExxonMobil and Chevron to do more to tackle the climate crisis.

headline: US pending home sales held steady in April
body: US pending home sales held steady in April, remaining unchanged after dropping in March, according to data released Thursday by the National Association of Realtors. After beating expectations in February, the pending home sales index dropped in March and was the first decline since November amid tight inventory and buyer uncertainty.

headline: AI chip boom sends Nvidia’s stock surging after whopper of a quarter
body: The AI boom is here, and Nvidia is reaping all the benefits. Shares of Nvidia exploded 28% higher Thursday after reporting earnings and sales that surged well above Wall Street’s already lofty expectations.

headline: Japan’s long-suffering stock market is back. This boom may have ‘staying power’
body: Japan’s stock market has waited more than three decades for its moment in the sun.

headline: Jamie Dimon warns of a commercial real estate downturn
body: Economists are concerned about the $20 trillion commercial real estate (CRE) industry and so is JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon.

headline: Markets latest: Housing data, jobless claims and banking regulators on the Hill
body: Wall Street closed higher Thursday for the second day, on optimism that a debt ceiling crisis can be averted. Traders also digested a slew of housing data, the latest jobless claims and another banking hearing.

headline: Angry lawmakers accuse Fed of inaction in insider trading investigation
body: Congressional lawmakers grilled Federal Reserve Inspector General Mark Bialek Wednesday over possible insider trading among Fed officials in 2020, accusing the nation’s central bank of inaction.

headline: Regional bank stocks soar after Western Alliance says deposits are growing
body: Regional bank stocks surged on Wednesday after Western Alliance reported that customer deposits are growing.

headline: Stock market updates: The latest on the debt ceiling, the economy and banking
body: The Senate Banking Committee is set to grill executives from failed banks Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. Markets will also be paying close attention to the latest retail sales and housing data for any signs that the economy is slowing.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway sells entire stake in TSMC
body: Warren Buffett’s conglomerate has sold its remaining shares in the world’s largest chipmaker, TSMC, after the “Oracle of Omaha” sounded alarms about its homebase of Taiwan.

headline: Turkish lira sinks to new record low on prospect of Erdogan re-election
body: Investors are nervously awaiting the outcome of Turkey’s presidential race in a runoff vote on May 28. They sent stocks tumbling Monday and pushed the value of its currency down to a new record low against the US dollar.

headline: The Fed probably won’t cut rates anytime soon. Why that’s good news for markets
body: Wall Street is eager to see the Federal Reserve wind down its aggressive rate-hiking cycle that’s battered markets and tested investor morale. Although a pause in interest rate hikes appears likely, cuts may be farther off than some believe.

headline: The latest on inflation and markets
body: Stocks closed mixed Wednesday after a better-than-expected inflation report, which showed price hikes continued to slow last month. That means the market now expects the Fed to pause its rate hike campaign that has helped bring inflation lower.

headline: The Fed would look ‘silly’ if it declares victory over inflation now, warns billionaire investor David Rubenstein
body: Wall Street is betting the Federal Reserve will reverse course and begin slashing interest rates as soon as this summer. Billionaire David Rubenstein is warning that would be a mistake.

headline: Why bank stocks are so unstable
body: The financial sector has been churning in rough water since the shocking collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway reports jump in earnings and holds annual meeting
body: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway reported a jump in earnings in the first quarter of 2023 ahead of the Oracle of Omaha’s annual shareholders meeting.

headline: Markets close higher on strong jobs report, rebound in regional banking stocks
body: Markets closed higher on Friday as regional banking stocks pared their losses after a volatile week and the monthly jobs report showed the US economy added a surprising 253,000 jobs last month.

headline: This is how the banking crisis ends
body: US regional bank stocks veered wildly on Thursday and Friday, accentuating fears that federal regulators have not yet contained a crisis in the sector that could shake the financial system.

headline: Paramount shares plunge more than 25% following dismal earnings
body: Paramount Global shares plunged more than 25% after a dismal first-quarter earnings report. Citing a weak advertising market in its TV business, the company also cut its dividend sharply.

headline: Why these bank stocks aren’t getting crushed
body: JPMorgan Chase’s rescue of First Republic Bank in the United States this week didn’t herald the end of the banking crisis.

headline: The latest on the Fed’s quarter-point rate hike
body: The Federal Reserve continued its streak of rate hikes, announcing a quarter-point rate hike on Wednesday, its 10th increase since March 2022.

headline: The Fed lifts rates by a quarter point
body: The Federal Reserve voted unanimously to raise interest rates by a quarter point Wednesday, the tenth rate hike since the central bank started its battle against inflation last March.

headline: Worse to come for the economy as rates top 5%
body: The Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise its benchmark interest rate again on Wednesday, lifting it above 5% for the first time since 2006 as it works to bring down stubborn inflation.

headline: Opinion: It makes no sense for the Fed to raise interest rates this week
body: The Federal Reserve is gearing up for another interest rate hike on Wednesday. But that would be a mistake, writes Mark Zandi. After an astonishing year of rate increases, it’s time for the Fed to pause.

headline: The latest on JPMorgan Chase takeover of First Republic Bank
body: JPMorgan Chase is buying most assets of First Republic Bank after the nation’s second-largest bank failure ever, in a deal announced early Monday after a weekend of negotiations. Follow here for live updates.

headline: Wall Street wants clarity from Fed meeting and jobs data
body: After a jam-packed week of earnings, bank drama and mixed inflation data, Wall Street doesn’t have time for a breather just yet.

headline: ExxonMobil, Chevron earnings down from record levels but top forecasts
body: Despite falling gas prices, ExxonMobil and Chevron reported bumper profits last quarter. While they were lower than last year, they still beat Wall Street forecasts, as well as where they were ahead of the spike in energy prices that followed the invasion of Ukraine more than a year ago.

headline: Markets digest banking issues, quarterly earnings and economic data
body: Markets are watching closely for further signs of stress in the financial sector, amid struggles at San Francisco lender First Republic Bank and a slew of economic reports that indicate a slowdown in growth.

headline: Google and Microsoft fight over the future of AI
body: Wall Street was able to breathe a sigh of relief on Tuesday as Google-parent company Alphabet and Microsoft both beat the market’s relatively modest earnings expectations. The companies saw big boosts from their search and cloud computing businesses.

headline: First Republic stocks drops nearly 50% after plunge in deposits
body: First Republic stock plunged by nearly 50% at the close of trading on Tuesday, hitting a new record low after the embattled lender reported late Monday that its total deposits fell 41% in the first quarter, to $104.5 billion, even after a consortium of banks stepped in with $30 billion to prevent the regional lender from failing. Without that cash infusion, deposits would have fallen by over 50%.

headline: US home prices rose slightly in February, snapping seven months of declines
body: US home prices rose slightly in February, snapping a seven-month streak of month-over-month declines, according to the latest S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller US National Home Price Index, released Tuesday.

headline: The banking crisis may have set the stage for an IPO comeback
body: Warnings of recession are widespread, inflation is still elevated and so are interest rates. Russia continues to wage war in Ukraine and markets are whipsawing around as investors try to make sense of it all. In short: The global macroeconomic picture is bleak.

headline: Democratic senators want to ban stock trading in Congress
body: Last year, the S&P 500 fell 18%, but you wouldn’t know it from looking at the portfolios of US lawmakers.

headline: Big Tech earnings are on deck this week. Why that matters
body: With Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon and Meta Platforms all slated to report earnings this coming week, investors are turning their attention away from bank earnings to Big Tech.

headline: Google CEO Sundar Pichai made $226 million last year
body: Google’s top executive took home quite a bit of money last year.

headline: Is Big Oil running out of gas?
body: Oil and gas stocks have been on a two-year tear, ripping ahead as natural gas prices surged due to supply chain kinks, a strong economy, and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Fears of a recession are now slamming on the brakes.

headline: Tesla shares plunge on lower prices, tighter profit margins
body: Tesla has cut the prices of its EVs repeatedly this year. Now investors are cutting the price of its shares.

headline: The earnings recession is here. There could be worse to come
body: Earnings reports are coming thick and fast, showing how companies fared in the first few months of the year. But analysts and investors are far more interested in what the future holds. As the saying goes, past performance is no guarantee of future results, and investors on Wall Street know that better than anyone.

headline: Apple is giving banks a run for their money
body: Apple and Goldman Sachs launched a new high-yield savings account on Monday that offers a 4.15% interest rate, more than 10 times higher than the US national average.

headline: Google-parent stock drops on fears it could lose search market share to AI-powered rivals
body: Shares of Google-parent Alphabet fell more than 3% in early trading Monday after a report sparked concerns that its core search engine could lose market share to AI-powered rivals, including Microsoft’s Bing.

headline: JPMorgan steals the show as banks lift curtain on earnings
body: First quarter earnings season kicked off last week with reports from some of the largest names in finance with investors watching closely for any potential inklings of an economic downturn.

headline: Markets digest bank earnings after recent turmoil
body: First-quarter earnings for companies in the S&P 500 kick off this week, and economists are predicting the biggest earnings decline since the onset of the pandemic.

headline: Why European stocks are crushing US peers
body: For years, global investors preferred American stocks to European ones. But at a time of change in financial markets, favor is shifting.

headline: This investor can spot market bubbles. Now he’s warning of an ‘ominous’ bust
body: Jeremy Grantham made his name predicting the dot-com crash in 2000 and the financial crisis in 2008. Now, the famous investor warns another epic bubble in financial markets is bursting — and the turmoil that swept through the banking sector last month is just the beginning.

headline: US inflation just reached an inflection point
body: After more than a year of soaring prices monopolizing the attention of Wall Street, Main Street, economists, and journalists, the tide may be turning.

headline: Main Street investors bet on comeback for regional banks
body: Banking crisis be damned – Main Street investors are barreling into embattled bank stocks. It turns out nothing tempts people to bet on an industry more than bargain prices, even if they’re caused by the fear of imminent collapse.

headline: Wall Street has found something else to worry about
body: March’s banking crisis commandeered the headlines and monopolized Wall Street’s attention over the past few weeks, but that doesn’t mean other concerns fell to the wayside. Sticky inflation remains the Federal Reserve’s number one concern and this week’s Consumer Price Index will have a material impact on whether the central bank raises rates again in May.

headline: What markets are watching after digesting the US jobs data
body: In an unusual coincidence, the US jobs report was released on a holiday Friday — meaning stock markets were closed when the closely-watched economic data came out.

headline: Wall Street says bad news is no longer good news. Here’s why
body: There’s been a seismic shift in investor perspective: Bad news is no longer good news.

headline: These are the only stocks that matter right now
body: US stocks have been incredibly resilient this year. In the midst of a banking crisis, historically high interest rates, geopolitical turmoil and heightened recession forecasts, the S&P 500 is up nearly 7% year-to-date. But investors should be wary, warn analysts, because the churn under the surface shows noticeable weakness.

headline: Stocks bounced back in the first quarter, but it’s too early to celebrate
body: After a stormy 2022, US stocks gained during the first quarter of 2023 in a surprise show of resilience despite a banking crisis, cryptocurrency meltdowns and uncertainty about what’s ahead for the economy.

headline: Stocks finished the quarter surprisingly strong. What’s next?
body: After a stormy 2022, US stocks gained during the first quarter of 2023 in a surprise show of resilience despite a banking crisis, cryptocurrency meltdowns and uncertainty about what’s ahead for the economy.

headline: Trump-related stocks surge after indictment
body: Three stocks with ties to former President Donald Trump surged Friday after two sources familiar with the case told CNN that Trump faces 30 counts related to business fraud in an indictment from a Manhattan grand jury.

headline: ‘Companies are holding out’: Global IPO market slump endures
body: A slowdown in global initial public offerings continued in the first quarter of 2023 and is likely to endure in the coming months, as companies wait out the effects of volatile stock markets, higher interest rates and inflation, and uncertainty around the banking crisis.

headline: Federal regulators are back on Capitol Hill to explain the banking crisis
body: US financial regulators are on Capitol Hill for a second day, testifying before the House Financial Services Committee on Wednesday to discuss the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank.

headline: Corporate greed is jacking prices higher. It could push customers over the edge
body: Inflation is ravaging shoppers’ wallets and the Federal Reserve has responded by instituting a regimen of painful interest rate hikes that could land the economy in a recession. But corporate profits are surging. US profit margins have reached record levels not seen since the immediate aftermath of World War II.

headline: Banking chaos could break the strong job market
body: The job market has remained strong even as the Federal Reserve has spent a full year attempting to cool off the economy by raising interest rates. But economists think that the recent banking turmoil may be what finally raises unemployment.

headline: Europe’s banking stocks recover as SVB deal brings respite
body: European banking stocks rose Monday, boosted by the news that US lender First Citizens Bank would buy most of the business of failed Silicon Valley Bank.

headline: Latest on global markets and banking crisis
body: Global markets were rattled again by two new problems, injecting a new dose of fear into an already on-edge banking sector.

headline: Deutsche Bank, UBS stocks sink as fear of European banking crisis returns
body: Europe’s banking stocks tumbled Friday as investors acted on their lingering worries that the recent crises at some banks could spill over into the wider sector.

headline: Americans are going all-in on cash. That could spell more trouble
body: In the wake of Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse and subsequent banking meltdown, cash is king. The turmoil inflicted on financial markets has sent cautious investors running away from volatile markets and toward more liquid alternatives.

headline: Five big takeaways from the Fed’s extraordinary meeting
body: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter percentage point on Wednesday as it attempts to fight stubbornly high inflation while addressing risks to financial stability.

headline: Global markets mixed after US Fed raises rates by a quarter-point
body: European and Asian markets were mixed during Thursday trade as investors digested the decision by the US Federal Reserve to raise its main interest rate by 25 basis points in a bid to bring down inflation.

headline: Fed raises rates by a quarter point
body: The Fed’s Open Market Committee concluded its meeting Wednesday and the central bank approved a quarter-point interest rate hike. Follow here for live updates.

headline: Asia Pacific shares join US gains as investors await key Fed decision
body: Asia Pacific shares opened higher on Wednesday, tracking US gains, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve’s next monetary policy decision later in the day.

headline: Latest on the banking crisis and global markets
body: US stock futures and global markets rose Tuesday after coordinated action by the Federal Reserve and other leading central banks to keep dollars flowing around the financial system appears to have calmed nerves for now.

headline: Global stocks rise as investor worries about banking turmoil ease
body: Stocks around the world rose Tuesday as concerns about the global banking sector eased in response to a whirlwind of intervention by policymakers and industry players.

headline: Five questions for the Federal Reserve as the banking crisis drags on
body: The Federal Reserve has a lot of balls in the air: Central bank officials are attempting to juggle their economic goals of maximum employment and price stability while maintaining financial safety and security in the midst of a banking meltdown.

headline: First Republic shares tumble to a new low
body: First Republic’s stock fell 47% to a record low Monday, as the bank struggled to persuade Wall Street it could remain viable.

headline: European markets recover on a wild day for bank stocks
body: European markets ticked up Monday but bank stocks were mixed and volatile as investors assessed the significance of the near-collapse of Credit Suisse, one of the world’s most important financial institutions.

headline: Silicon Valley Bank left a void that won’t easily be filled
body: It’s difficult to overstate the influence that Silicon Valley Bank had over the startup world and the ripple effect its collapse this month had on the global tech sector and banking system.

headline: Latest on banks and global markets
body: Shares in Credit Suisse surged on Thursday after it agreed to a $53 billion loan from the Swiss central bank. And in the US, First Republic Bank is set to receive a $30 billion lifeline from a group of 11 large banks. Follow for live updates.

headline: Global markets rebound after US lenders rescue First Republic Bank
body: Markets in Europe and Asia rebounded Friday after First Republic Bank was rescued by a group of major US lenders, easing worries about the current banking turmoil.

headline: The banking meltdown put the Fed in a bind
body: With just a few days to go until the Federal Reserve’s next interest rate decision, US policymakers are sitting between a rock and a hard place.

headline: Global markets react to Credit Suisse deal as fears hit bank stocks
body: Switzerland’s central bank said it was ready to provide financial support to Credit Suisse after shares in the country’s second-biggest lender crashed as much as 30%. Follow for live updates.

headline: Dow falls 500 points as banking fears spread
body: The Dow opened the day with a decline of more than 500 points Wednesday as banking fears spread across global markets, though the index pared losses to close the day down about 281 points, or 0.9%.

headline: There’s plenty of blame to go around for SVB’s collapse

headline: Why today’s inflation report is so important
body: Federal Reserve policy is based on trust. The central bank’s ability to maintain stable prices depends on the public’s confidence that it can deliver. But after more than a year of interest rate hikes and attempts to cool the economy, prices are still rising at a pace well above the Fed’s 2% goal and the public is becoming increasingly weary.

headline: Big Retail’s cautious forecasts are spooking Wall Street

The mega retailers’ predictions of a weakening economy and a dip in consumer spending this year sent markets tumbling as Wall Street seemed to realize that the Federal Reserve’s campaign to quell inflation could yet lead to recession.

headline: Warren Buffett is missing out on this year’s market comeback

But after a brutal year in which the company lost more than $600 billion in market value, Zuckerberg has started speaking Wall Street’s language — and they are rewarding him for it.

headline: Goodbye 2022 – and good riddance. Markets close out their worst year since 2008
body: Wall Street has said goodbye — and good riddance — to 2022, a year most investors would rather forget.

headline: Wall Street kills its darlings
body: Verbose writers afflicted with the tendency to deliver copy well above their requested word count are often advised by editors to kill their darlings – to throw out large swaths of stories that they’re particularly fond of.

headline: Tesla shares are down 70% for the year as Morgan Stanley cuts price target
body: Tesla’s stock is finishing out its tumultuous year with yet more turbulence: It’s up almost 6% Thursday, but still down more than 10% since last week. And a new cut to its price target from Morgan Stanley isn’t helping.

headline: Wall Street’s biggest winners and losers in 2022
body: This hasn’t been a good year for the equities market. The S&P 500 is down nearly 20% and with two trading days left in the year, investors’ hopes of a miraculous recovery have been dashed.

headline: Wall Street’s dirty secret: It’s terrible at forecasting stocks
body: December is a month full of market predictions for the year to come. Everyone, from economists to analysts to grocers, seems to have a strong feeling about how stocks will behave going forward.

headline: Oil and Turkish stocks were 2022 market winners. Russia funds and crypto tanked
body: Oil stocks skyrocketed in 2022, so it’s no surprise funds that track the energy sector were Wall Street winners this year. But the top fund of the year is a surprising one: It invests in a variety of companies based in Turkey.

headline: Dow sinks after the US economy grew much faster than previously thought in the third quarter
body: The Dow sank as America’s economy grew much faster than previously thought in the third quarter, a sign that the Federal Reserve’s battle to cool the economy to fight inflation is having only a limited impact.

headline: Dow surges thanks to strong earnings and confident consumers
body: Here comes the Santa Claus market rally.

headline: Main Street’s buying stocks while Wall Street sells: What gives?

headline: Why the market is obsessed with unemployment
body: As the year comes to a close, it seems that the market’s focus on inflation rates are shifting to a new area of concern: Unemployment. While the Federal Reserve has taken steps to fight inflation by curbing economic growth, the full extent of the damage to the employment market is yet to be seen.

headline: The Dow fell nearly 300 points on Friday. Why stocks keep tumbling
body: The good vibes on Wall Street are fading fast: US slid tumbled yet again on Friday as investors come to grips with a souring economy.

headline: Dow tumbles on recession fears. So much for a Santa Claus rally

headline: Massive changes could be coming to the way the stock market functions
body: Wall Street’s top cop has voted in favor of major changes to the way millions of everyday investors buy and sell stocks.

headline: Elon Musk sells another 22 million Tesla shares for $3.6 billion
body: Elon Musk just sold another 22 million shares of Tesla, raising $3.6 billion.

headline: Stocks struggle after the Fed eases up on rate hikes

headline: Dow surges after inflation cools more than expected
body: Stocks rose after a consequential inflation report showed inflation cooled much more than expected.

headline: How the Fed could do a smaller rate hike and still upset markets

headline: Microsoft buys stake in London Stock Exchange owner in cloud data deal

headline: The Fed will raise rates again. But it’s playing with fire

headline: Americans’ wealth slips further after massive loss in the spring

headline: Big Oil stocks are pointing to higher gas prices to come

headline: Stocks close higher, breaking five day losing streak
body: US stocks surged higher on Thursday as investors staged a comeback from their current losing streak, spurred on by recession and interest rate hike fears.

headline: The media business is in turmoil — but its stocks may be close to bottoming

headline: Companies can’t imagine life without the CEO. That’s a problem
body: Nothing lasts forever, not even a good CEO.

headline: Meme stock mania may finally be over

headline: Jay Powell’s dream of the 90s is dead
body: The US economy gained 263,000 jobs in November, 63,000 above the consensus estimate. The larger surprise was that average hourly earnings rose by 0.55%, the fastest pace since January.

headline: Is the worst over for bitcoin and the rest of crypto?
body: The meltdown of FTX has sent the price of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies tumbling more than 60% this year…and the carnage has spread to publicly traded companies with exposure to digital assets.

headline: Stocks tumble after better-than-expected jobs report
Dow in bull market after Powell suggests rate hikes will ease
body: The stock market will respond to reports on GDP and jobs, speeches by Jerome Powell and Janet Yellen, and to business leaders speaking at the DealBook conference Wednesday.

headline: Why the stock market is channeling Goldilocks
body: The global economy is weakening and consumers are feeling financially stressed. Gas and heat prices are up significantly from last year and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell indicated on Wednesday that painfully elevated interest rates will hang around for some time.

headline: What the heck happened to Salesforce?
body: Tech stocks have taken a nasty tumble this year, but some are doing even worse than others. Exhibit A: software giant Salesforce.

headline: Dow tumbles 500 points but could actually end the year in the green

headline: Is the dollar’s relentless rise coming to an end?
body: The story of financial markets and the global economy this year has been written in part by the dramatic rise of the US dollar, whose inexorable ascent has sent shockwaves around the world. At last, however, its breakneck rally could be coming to an end.

headline: Recession fears receded this earnings season

headline: Investors have very little to be thankful for in 2022

headline: Fed officials crushed investors’ hopes this week
