headline: Stocks fall as fears of more big Fed rate hikes resurface
body: Wall Street cares only about one thing right now…and it’s not earnings, the state of the job market, resilient consumer spending or the spectacular FTX/crypto meltdown. Investors are laser-focused on the Federal Reserve and what central bankers are saying about inflation and rates.

headline: Greed is back with a vengeance on Wall Street
body: Many investors are still nursing losses for the year. But stocks have come roaring back to life in the past few weeks thanks to hopes that inflation might be really peaking and that the Federal Reserve will soon reduce or slow down its interest rate increases as a result. Wall Street is now, dare we say, almost giddy.

headline: It’s looking grim for Wall Street bonuses this year
body: Ferragamo belt-buckles are being tightened across Wall Street as bankers prepare for a gloomy bonus season. Year-end payouts, typically an outsized part of total financial industry compensation, are expected to plunge as merger and acquisitions dry up, inflation persists and recession threats grow.

headline: Inflation is cooling, and Wall Street loves it
body: Stocks ended the day higher Tuesday after the US government reported that wholesale prices rose at a far less dramatic rate than expected. That news come just a few days after another report showed that the pace of consumer price increases was also slowing.

headline: Warren Buffett’s company buys $4 billion stake in Taiwanese chip giant TSMC
body: Shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company surged on Tuesday after Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had purchased a $4.1 billion stake in one of the world’s largest chipmakers.

headline: Tech stocks have been crushed. What’s next for the FAANGs?
body: The great bull run for tech stocks may finally be over. It has been a brutal year for the leading companies of Silicon Valley. How bad as it been? Consider this. Apple is down about 16% in 2022…and that makes it the “best” performer in Big Tech.

headline: Crypto is in crisis. It’s not just because of FTX
body: The stunning downfall of FTX, one of the largest cryptocurrency exchanges, sent shockwaves through the crypto universe last week. Sam Bankman-Fried, the 30-year-old crypto titan and chief executive of FTX, watched billions of his fortune evaporate in a bankruptcy filing that shook the trillion-dollar industry to its core. The pain likely isn’t over for investors.

headline: Wall Street picks hope over reality… again
body: Stocks surged on Thursday in their best day since 2020 after a key inflation indicator came in softer than expected. Investors broke out their party hats as they interpreted the report to mean that peak inflation may finally be behind us. That means the Federal Reserve could be less aggressive with its rate hikes.

headline: A better-than-expected inflation report sends stocks surging
body: The Consumer Price Index, another key inflation report showed annual price growth continued to slip in October. The 7.7% annual price growth remained high though much better than expected after the Fed maintained its historic pace of rate hikes.

headline: This is the moment Wall Street has been waiting for
body: Stocks soared in their best day since 2020 on Thursday after new economic data showed that price increases eased in October. Investors cheered the development because it indicates the Federal Reserve’s interest rate hikes may finally be cooling inflation.

headline: Stocks slip as control of Congress remains unclear
body: Wall Street was betting on a red wave in the midterm elections Tuesday. But it appears that didn’t happen. And investors saw red on their trading screens Wednesday.

headline: Markets are in trouble. Election results won’t change that
body: The results of Tuesday’s midterm elections will set the agenda for the next Congress. That could mean changes to fiscal policy, which uses taxes and government spending to influence a country’s economy.

headline: Stock futures mostly unchanged as election results roll in
body: US stocks were mostly unchanged in premarket trading as results from Tuesday’s midterm elections rolled in.

headline: Stocks rise as Americans head to the polls
body: #RedWave? #VoteBlue? Wall Street saw green on this midterm Election Day.

headline: Biden’s stock market record so far is the second worst since Jimmy Carter
body: The stock market under President Biden started with a boom, but it heads into the midterm elections looking more like a bust.

headline: Trump-linked SPAC stock goes bonkers ahead of midterms
body: Many political experts are predicting big Republican wins in the midterm elections that could give the GOP control of at least one, if not both, chambers of Congress. Investors have taken notice too.

headline: What will the Fed do next? Follow the economy, not what Jerome Powell says
body: The stock market has been on a roller coaster ride, largely because of Wall Street’s shifting expectations about whether the Federal Reserve is going to slow down the pace and size of its interest rate hikes.

headline: What the wave of tech layoffs tell us about the economy
body: Friday’s jobs report came in strong: the US economy added 261,000 new jobs in October, blowing away analyst expectations of 200,000, even as unemployment ticked up to 3.7%.

headline: How the midterms could affect Wall Street
body: Last week was a volatile one on Wall Street, with stocks falling after Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell dashed the market’s dreams of a pivot and suggested that more big rate hikes are likely coming. But Wall Street is still turning its hopes to Washington.

headline: Stocks in Hong Kong log best week in more than a decade
body: Global investors have two big questions on their minds: When will the Federal Reserve become less aggressive in its campaign against inflation? And does Beijing plan to ease its strict “zero-Covid” policy any time soon?

headline: Interest rates will keep rising. How high will they go?
body: What will the Federal Reserve do at its meeting in December? Analysts can speculate all they want, but Fed officials say they will be using hard economic data to make their next decision.

headline: Did Jerome Powell just bust the stock market rally?
body: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has the power to make or break markets these days. On Wednesday, he opted to disappoint.

headline: Stocks tumble after Fed signals rate hikes are here to stay
Wall Street’s recent love affair with the Fed could turn on a dime
body: Fed decision day is here — and so is some potential bad news for the market.

headline: Where are the unicorns? The IPO market has unraveled this year
body: Wall Street bulls may have come thundering back in October as bears appear to have gone into hibernation. But there’s another beast, albeit a mythical one, that has been pretty much absent from the stock market all year: Unicorns. There has been little demand for private companies to make their debuts with initial public offerings.

headline: Why America’s job market hasn’t imploded
body: Despite a stock-market bounce in October that gave the Dow its biggest monthly gain in more than 45 years, economists are warning that there’s a very real danger of recession in the United States. Mortgage rates are at their highest levels since 2002, consumer spending and business investment is falling and the Federal Reserve is fighting persistent inflation with higher interest rates.

headline: Dow has biggest monthly gain in more than 45 years
body: The Dow fell nearly 130 points, or 0.4% Monday, but it still ended October up 14% — its best monthly gain since January 1976. The blue chips remain off by almost 10% this year, though.

headline: A spooky forecast for the future of interest rates
body: When will central banks stop raising interest rates? That’s the multi-trillion dollar question that has Wall Street analysts wearing wrist braces from shaking their Magic 8 Balls so hard.

headline: The Fed may have to blow up the economy to get inflation under control
body: The Federal Reserve is most likely going to raise interest rates by three quarters of a percentage point again on Wednesday, its fourth straight supersized hike. And it’s still possible another rate increase of that magnitude could come in December.

headline: Dow surges more than 800 points on the back of record oil profits
body: Stocks rallied heading into the weekend, despite lousy results from Amazon. Solid earnings from Apple and record profits from oil giants Chevron and Exxon Mobil were enough to counter the weak outlook from the retail and cloud giant.

headline: McDonald’s stock hits all time high
body: McDonald’s stock hit an all time high Friday as Wall Street cheered the company’s third quarter results.

headline: ExxonMobil posts another record profit as oil prices remain high
body: America’s largest oil company ExxonMobil set a profit record for the second-straight quarter as oil and gas prices remained high. No. 2 US oil company Chevron also posted much-better-than-expected results.

headline: The Fed is killing the housing market
body: The US economy grew by a 2.6% adjusted annual rate in the third-quarter, bouncing back from two negative quarters and beating analyst expectations.

headline: Dow bursts higher after US economy grows more than expected
body: Here’s the latest news on what stocks are doing.

headline: Big Tech can’t save your investments
body: Tech stocks are taking a beating this week as they prove less resilient to the economic downturn than investors had hoped they would be.

headline: Meta’s stock falls 17% as its quarterly profit is cut in half
body: Meta on Wednesday posted the second quarterly revenue decline in its history since going public and warned that it is making “significant changes” aimed at cutting costs ahead of 2023, as it confronts an economic downturn that is hitting its core online advertising business.

headline: A key market indicator is signaling a recession
body: Recession worries continue to haunt Wall Street. A key indicator in the bond market is flashing signs of a potential downturn.

headline: Google’s core business is slowing down amid recession fears
body: Google may be the giant in the digital advertising world, but even it is not immune to the impact that the economic downturn and recession fears are having on the online ad market.

headline: Why stocks keep rallying even though consumers feel lousy
body: Consumers may be worried about inflation and rising interest rates. But don’t tell that to Wall Street.

headline: Stock picking isn’t dead. But for most investors it might as well be
body: What’s the best way to invest? Plenty of active traders are out there trying to make a quick buck on meme stocks like AMC and GameStop, fads like Snap and Peloton or bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. Professional money managers try to identify stocks that can beat the broader market over the long haul.

headline: GM earnings soar on improved supply chain issues
body: General Motors says its supply chain issues are improving. That allowed the company to post better-than-expected earnings despite falling short of revenue forecasts.

headline: The Fed may have changed markets forever
body: It’s safe to say that the global economy is in a pretty bad place right now: The vast majority of economists think we’re on the brink of recession. But US markets don’t seem to mind. Stocks closed out their best week since mid-June last Friday and continued that rally into Monday.

headline: Hong Kong stocks plunge 6% as fears about Xi’s third term trump China GDP data
body: Hong Kong stocks had their worst day since the 2008 global financial crisis, just a day after Chinese leader Xi Jinping secured his iron grip on power at a major political gathering.

headline: October surprise? Stocks continue to sizzle this month
body: October may be famous for historically horrifying stock market crashes like the ones in 1929, 1987 and 2008. But so far this month, there’s nothing for investors to be scared of on Wall Street. Stocks enjoyed another solid rally Monday, continuing a hot streak for the markets this month.

headline: Why investors aren’t going green
body: ESG investing —  evaluating companies using environmental, social and governance factors — was one of the most-cited phrases in earnings calls during the first half of the year. But a looming recession, tanking stock markets and the race to US midterm elections have put those sustainability efforts on the chopping block.

headline: US officials made lucrative stock trades while preparing for Covid-19, WSJ reports
body: Dozens of federal officials made lucrative stock and mutual fund trades in early 2020 as the government was preparing for the onslaught of Covid-19, according to a Wall Street Journal investigation.

headline: Stocks soar on hopes that Fed will slow rate hikes
body: A disastrous earnings report from Snap and less than inspiring results from Dow components American Express and Verizon weren’t enough to keep the Wall Street bulls at bay Friday. Stocks surged on hopes that the Federal Reserve may soon come to the rescue by slowing the pace of its rate hikes.

headline: Twitter stock falls after report says Biden admin weighing security review of Musk ventures
body: Shares of Twitter dropped as much as 8% in pre-market trading Friday as investors braced for some last-minute uncertainty around Elon Musk’s $44 billion deal to buy the company.

headline: The era of the meme trade is over
body: It’s been a tumultuous year for retail traders — people who buy shares of individual companies or indexes on popular trading platforms like Robinhood or E-Trade. Facing an economic outlook full of bear markets, high inflation and interest rate hikes, they’ve finally decided that they’ve had enough.

headline: Key US bond yield hits highest level since June 2008
body: More bad news for anyone looking to buy a home: The benchmark 10-year Treasury bond yield rose to about 4.23% Thursday afternoon, the highest level since June 2008. Mortgage rates, which are now hovering just below 7%, tend to move in lockstep with the 10-year yield.

headline: Beware of fad stocks. Truly owner, Snap and Zoom have plunged
body: Fads come and go in fashion. (Are skinny jeans no longer a thing?) The same is true of the stock market.

headline: The Fed isn’t about to back down from its inflation fight
body: Twelve days from now, the Federal Reserve will meet again, and expectations for the central bank’s next moves are firming up. The consensus among investors: Persistently hot inflation means the Fed will need to continue with its string of aggressive interest rate hikes, which is unprecedented in the modern era.

headline: Chinese stocks tumble to multi-year lows in New York and Hong Kong amid party congress
body: Chinese stocks have hit multi-year lows in New York and Hong Kong amid growing concerns about China’s rising Covid cases and economic outlook.

headline: It’s been 35 years since the epic Black Monday crash. What have investors learned?
body: October 19, 1987. A brief but violent stock market crash. Can it happen again?

headline: Stocks surge again as Corporate America’s earnings impress
body: So much for Shocktober. Wall Street’s often scary month for stocks has suddenly turned into Rocktober.

headline: Goldman Sachs overhauls banking and trading units
body: Goldman Sachs announced a major reorganization Tuesday as the Wall Street powerhouse grapples with market volatility.

headline: The strong dollar has an unexpected victim
body: The strong dollar has been a headwind for blue chip US companies in the Dow and S&P 500 this year.

headline: Dow soars back above 30,000
body: Stocks rallied sharply Monday, thanks to more strong earnings from big banks and a sigh of relief about new plans by the United Kingdom to scrap a controversial tax cut plan.

headline: US bank earnings revealed ominous clues about the future of the housing market
body: The largest US banks reported relatively solid third-quarter earnings on Friday. But within those reports, investors found ominous clues about the future of the housing market, underscoring fears of an upcoming crisis.

headline: Tesla investors try to look past Elon Musk’s many, many distractions
body: Elon Musk now wants to buy Twitter after all. While that’s good news for Twitter’s long-suffering shareholders, Tesla investors hope he still has some time for them. They need a little help, too.

headline: Stocks slide in volatile trading session
body: Here’s the latest news on what stocks are doing.

headline: Top Fed official says he broke central bank trading rules
body: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said Friday he had inadvertently broken the central bank’s trading rules.

headline: A ‘tectonic shift’ in global wealth that will take years to recover from
body: Markets plunged on Thursday morning after red-hot inflation data raised fears on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve would continue hiking interest rates aggressively. Then, something strange happened.

headline: Stocks roar back after plunging at the opening bell
body: Here’s the latest news on what stocks are doing.

headline: How to read big bank earnings
body: If market swings tell us anything, it’s that investors are rattled by economic uncertainty. The outlook remains cloudy with the possibility of recession on the horizon. Big bank earnings, coming Friday, could help clear some of that fog.

headline: Markets are worried the Fed is going too far
body: A closely watched measure of inflation in the United States is expected to tick higher in September even as the Federal Reserve moves to fight rising prices at its most aggressive pace in decades. Wall Street is worried that yet another high reading on the Consumer Price Index will prompt another massive interest rate increase and inflict more pain on markets and the US economy.

headline: Don’t worry, there’s still hope for the stock market
body: The back-to-back, huge market rallies of last week may seem like a distant memory to investors after stocks slid for the past four days and finished mixed Tuesday.

headline: Markets won’t go back to normal until the Fed stops hiking rates
body: Stocks lost ground again on Monday following a turbulent week that saw market volatility at its bumpiest level since July.

headline: Stocks dip after JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon warns of recession
body: So much for a sleepy Columbus Day on Wall Street. Stocks weren’t doing much Monday morning but took a turn lower in the afternoon following stark comments from JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, who warned that the United States is likely to enter a recession within the next six to nine months.

headline: White-collar workers are feeling the brunt of the Fed’s rate hikes. Here’s why
body: September’s hotly anticipated jobs data ended up cooling markets on Friday. Stocks fell sharply as investors evaluated the report, which showed more jobs than expected were added to the US economy and indicated that more pain-inflicting interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve lie ahead.

headline: Get ready for some earnings
body: There’s lots of anxiety swirling about a possible recession. Is Corporate America starting to get nervous, too? We’ll get a better sense this week when several top financial firms and consumer companies report third-quarter earnings.

headline: Stocks sink after hotter-than-expected jobs report
body: Here’s the latest news on what stocks are doing.

headline: Why good news for the economy is bad news for stocks and the Fed
body: It’s not the fall that kills you, as the saying goes — it’s the sudden stop at the bottom.

headline: OPEC’s production cut is a win for oil stocks
body: The White House isn’t very happy with OPEC’s decision to slash oil production by 2 million barrels per day. Consumers won’t be big fans either, as the move will likely send gas prices higher.

headline: AMD revenue warning signals deep chip slump; shares dive 4%
body: Chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices Inc on Thursday provided third-quarter revenue estimates that were about a billion dollars less than previously forecast, signaling the chip slump could be much worse than expected.

headline: Markets are starting to act super strange
body: Investors are tightening their neck braces as US stocks soar upwards, plummet back down and then do it all over. Stock market volatility is at its bumpiest level since July.

headline: Stocks end Wednesday slightly lower following huge two-day surge
body: Maybe that October market rally has some legs after all?

headline: The bond market is crumbling. That’s bad for Wall Street and Main Street
body: The global bond market is having a historically awful year.

headline: Here’s who made Fortune’s Most Powerful Women in Business list for 2022
body: The top of Fortune’s 2022 list is similar to last year’s. But there is one new executive in the top 5.

headline: Dow rallies more than 1,500 points in two days as fear begins to fade
body: Is the worst really over on Wall Street? It’s too soon to say. But stocks rose sharply again Tuesday following Monday’s big rally.

headline: Micron to invest up to $100 billion to build chip factory in upstate New York
body: Micron on Tuesday said it would invest up to $100 billion over the next two decades to build a massive semiconductor factory in upstate New York. The move comes in the wake of US government efforts to boost domestic chip production.

headline: Stocks kick off October with a huge rally
body: Stocks kicked off October with more treats than tricks for investors. The market rallied to begin the fourth quarter, despite growing worries about the financial health of European banking giant Credit Suisse and weak economic data.

headline: Welcome to the fourth quarter. Expect more gloom but less doom
body: It’s been a hard year for markets, and investors are looking for a bit of reprieve as we enter the fourth quarter — historically a good one for stocks, especially during midterm election years. Unfortunately, this year may buck the trend.

headline: Credit Suisse stock falls to fresh record low as investor concerns mount
body: Shares of Credit Suisse plunged to a fresh record low on Monday as jittery investors trained their attention on the Swiss bank.

headline: Dow suffers worst month since March 2020
body: September was a horrible month for stocks. The Dow fell nearly 9%, its worst monthly drop since March 2020, when pandemic lockdowns started in the United States. The index ended Friday deeply in the red, too.

headline: Can Porsche cure an ailing IPO market?
body: Warnings of global recession are widespread, inflation is persistent and Russia is escalating the crisis in Europe. The macro picture for the economy is bleak, and markets are suffering. But in the midst of all of this turmoil, luxury automaker Porsche managed to make one of the biggest market debuts in European history on Thursday.

headline: Led by Hong Kong, Asian stocks on track to suffer worst month since Covid began
body: Asian markets are careening toward their worst month since the Covid pandemic began, hit by a mighty US dollar and rising global recession fears.

headline: Dow plunges and is back in a bear market
body: The third quarter is about to end – and investors are wishing the past nine months good riddance. Stocks fell Thursday, giving up much of Wednesday’s big gains. The Dow fell nearly 460 points, or 1.5%.

headline: Mortgage rates surge, closing in on 7%
body: Mortgage rates surged for the sixth week in a row, moving closer to 7%.

headline: Porsche shares gain 5% in Frankfurt stock market debut
body: Shares of Porsche gained as much as 5% on their stock market debut in Frankfurt after Volkswagen spun out the premium sports car maker in one of Europe’s biggest listings on record.

headline: Stocks, bonds rally after Bank of England says it will buy UK debt
body: US stocks and bonds rallied Wednesday after the Bank of England said it would buy UK government debt “on whatever scale is necessary” in an emergency intervention to halt a bond market crash.

headline: Apple stock drops on concerns about iPhone 14 demand
body: Shares of Apple fell 4% in early trading Wednesday amid concerns about demand for the company’s latest lineup of iPhones.

headline: Global markets drop after rocky day on Wall Street
body: Asian and European stocks fell Wednesday after another turbulent day for US markets, as investors continue to sell off amid fears of global inflation, further interest rate hikes and broader economic turmoil.

headline: Stocks finish mixed, but Dow and S&P hit lowest levels since November 2020
body: So much for turnaround Tuesday on Wall Street. Stocks finished a volatile day mixed after rallying at the open. The Dow and S&P 500 are at their lowest levels since November 2020 and are both on a six-day losing streak.

headline: Wall Street slumps as sinking British pound rattles markets
body: US markets were mostly flat after the British pound crashed to a new record low against the dollar Monday morning. Follow live here.

headline: Forget a soft landing. The market’s best hope is a ‘growth’ recession
body: Investors are waking up to the harsh reality of just how much pain the economy may have to endure as the Federal Reserve continues its fight against stubbornly high inflation.

headline: Intel is the Dow’s biggest loser
body: Semiconductors are in everything. Our phones, our laptops, our televisions. Even our cars. But concerns about a global recession and continued worries about supply shortages stemming from lingering pandemic-related shutdowns in Asia over the past two years are hurting top chip companies.

headline: Dow plunges to its lowest level since 2020 to end another dismal week
body: US stocks fell sharply in Friday trading as investors continued to worry about even more rate hikes from the Federal Reserve that could land the US economy in a recession.

headline: Goldman Sachs warns of more trouble for US stocks
body: Even Goldman Sachs is succumbing to the gloomy mood on Wall Street by abandoning its previously optimistic stance and warning that US stocks will end the year deeply in the red.

headline: Oil plunges below $80 to eight-month low as recession fears mount
body: Recession fears are slamming the oil market, with crude tumbling on Friday below $80 a barrel for the first time since January.

headline: Boeing agrees to pay $200 million for misleading the public about the 737 Max
body: Boeing and its former CEO Dennis Muilenburg agreed to pay hefty fines to settle charges from the Securities and Exchange Commission that they misled the public about the safety of the 737 Max following two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019.

headline: FedEx hikes package rates for 2023
body: FedEx will raise ground and express shipping rates by an average of 6.9% next year, the company said Thursday. Freight rates will increase by an average of 6.9% to 7.9%.

headline: Mortgage rates rise to nearly 6.3%, the highest level since 2008
body: Mortgage rates jumped higher for the fifth week in a row, further pushing past 6% in the face of yet another aggressive interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve.

headline: Hong Kong stocks hit an 11-year low after historic Fed rate hike
body: Hong Kong stocks hit their lowest level in more than a decade Thursday and other Asian markets also fell after the US Federal Reserve raised rates by 75 basis points and forecast even more hikes ahead, fueling concerns about a recession.

headline: Fed goes big again with third-straight three-quarter-point rate hike
body: The Federal Reserve made history on Wednesday, approving a third consecutive 75-basis-point hike in an aggressive move to tackle the white-hot inflation that has been plaguing the US economy.

headline: September 21, 2022: Fed raises interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point
body: Here’s the latest news on what the Fed is doing.

headline: Stocks sink as investors wait for the Fed’s rate hike
body: So much for Wall Street sitting back and taking it easy while awaiting the Federal Reserve’s latest interest rate decision on Wednesday. Stocks slid Tuesday as investors grew anxious about the impact of another big rate hike.

headline: Wonder where the economy is heading? Keep an eye on earnings
body: Corporate America is starting to brace for a recession.

headline: Inflation is stubbornly high. Here’s what this bank exec suggests you do
body: People around the world are looking for ways to hedge against inflation right now, and the rich are no exception. “We see customers sitting a little bit in the sidelines,” says Nuno Matos, HSBC CEO of wealth management and personal banking.

headline: Anxious investors are piling into hedge funds
body: For years, the climate for hedge funds was tough. Volatility was low. The price of everything was going up. It wasn’t that hard to make money. In that type of environment, why think outside the box?

headline: Stocks close higher ahead of Federal Reserve meeting
body: US stocks alternated between slight losses and modest gains Monday before eventually closing higher ahead of the Federal Reserve’s two-day policy meeting later this week.

headline: Volkswagen targets 75 billion euro valuation in landmark Porsche IPO
body: Volkswagen is targeting a valuation of up to 75 billion euros ($75.1 billion) for luxury sportscar maker Porsche, it said on Sunday, in what will be Germany’s second-largest initial public offering (IPO) in history.

headline: An Indian tycoon just ousted Jeff Bezos as world’s second-richest person
body: Jeff Bezos just lost his status as the world’s second-richest person, dropping to No. 3 as Indian business mogul Gautam Adani rapidly climbs the ranks of Bloomberg’s Billionaire Index.

headline: Another big rate hike is coming. Lather. Rinse. Repeat
body: The Federal Reserve’s upcoming meeting on Wednesday will be one for the history books. The Fed will either raise rates by three-quarters of a point for the third consecutive time, to 3%, or it will hike them by an unprecedented one full percentage point to 3.25%.

headline: FedEx warns of a global recession, cutting sales forecast by half a billion dollars
body: FedEx warned that a global recession could be coming, as demand for packages around the world tumbles.

headline: Stocks fall after FedEx warns of global recession
body: US stocks fell on Friday after FedEx served investors a brutal pre-earnings announcement about the state of the global economy.

headline: It’s getting late in the game. Will the Fed risk a Hail Mary?
body: Investors are on edge as the Federal Reserve gears up for its policy decision next week. Some are even starting to brace for a big surprise.

headline: As markets wobble, buy the stocks that pay you back
body: Tuesday’s massive stock market meltdown should serve as a reminder to investors that in times of turmoil, it pays to own shares of companies that also pay you.

headline: The Fed could crash the housing market
body: Investors are getting spooked that the Federal Reserve can’t pull off aggressive interest rate hikes without significantly damaging the US economy (just look at Tuesday’s selloff).

headline: Google loses appeal against record $4 billion EU fine
body: Google suffered one of its biggest setbacks on Wednesday when a top European court fined it 4.125 billion euros ($4.13 billion) for using its Android mobile operating system to thwart rivals, offering a precedent for other regulators to ratchet up pressure.

headline: Markets steady after worst day for US stocks since June 2020
body: Markets steadied early Wednesday after US stocks logged their worst day since June 2020, plunging on news that inflation in August was higher than expected.

headline: Dow tumbles as America’s prices keep rising
body: Here’s the latest news on what stocks are doing.

headline: Ukraine’s surprising comeback could be giving markets a boost
body: Ukrainian forces have made sweeping advances in September in their fight against Russia, easing some investor fears of a prolonged war-induced energy crisis in Europe.

headline: Fed officials to markets: You can’t stop us
body: The US Federal Reserve is delivering a hawkish message to markets: We hear you, we see you, but you can’t stop us — aggressive rate hikes aren’t going away.

headline: AMC’s hype machine can’t fix the broken economics of movie theaters
body: Movie theater chain AMC is a top pick for meme investors, but the stock hasn’t exactly turned out to be the feel good hit of this summer.

headline: Reality is setting in for GameStop stock
body: Billionaire Ryan Cohen profited big when he briefly invested in struggling retailer Bed Bath & Beyond and helped it become a meme stock again. Now he faces an arguably tougher challenge with another of the original meme phenoms: GameStop.

headline: Burr avoided tens of thousands in losses with ‘well-timed’ stock sales in beginning of pandemic
body: Sen. Richard Burr avoided about $87,000 of losses when he sold off stock at the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic, according to a 2020 search warrant affidavit unsealed on Monday.

headline: How do you like them Apples? Stock could get an iPhone 14 pop
body: Apple’s stock has been a lemon this year. Shares are down more than 10% so far in 2022, and Apple is trading about 15% below the all-time high it hit in early January.

headline: Oil’s still well for energy stocks
body: Move over, Big Tech: Oil just might be the new FAANG.

headline: Stocks start off September with a late day rally
body: New month. Same old market volatility.

headline: Mortgage rates rise again after Fed says it will take ‘forceful’ steps to curb inflation
body: Mortgage rates continued to climb this week following comments by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell that the central bank is taking “forceful and rapid” steps to reduce inflation and slow the economy.

headline: Wall Street’s biggest fear gauge is broken
body: Markets are hard to predict right now, and that’s raising a question for some on Wall Street: Does a common measure of volatility actually work the way it should?

headline: Don’t expect home prices to come crashing down anytime soon
body: Rising mortgage rates are taking a toll on the US housing market. But those hoping for prices to drop probably won’t catch a break anytime soon.

headline: China stocks hit four-week low as Covid cases spread and factory output shrinks
body: Chinese markets fell on Wednesday as global investors continue to deal with the aftermath of Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell’s hawkish speech at Jackson Hole last week, and the alarming spread of Covid in China.

headline: So much for turnaround Tuesday? Stocks tumble again
body: Tuesday’s market rally was brief. Stocks opened higher but quickly gave up their gains. A more than 5% drop in oil prices, while welcome news to consumers, led to a big sell-off in energy stocks.

headline: Rich people are worried about spending. That’s bad news for everyone else
body: It’s looking like Americans are feeling better about the economy this month. But a closer look at the numbers shows a more concerning picture.

headline: Stocks slip in volatile trading as investors prepare for more big rate hikes

And they tend not to ask executives tough questions on earnings calls, leaning toward a more “Great quarter, guys!” approach.

headline: Has the bear market really gone into early hibernation?

headline: Why junk food stocks are surging

The past two and a half years, full of public health crises, recession and inflation, have been so eventful that news of a possible alien invasion barely even made a blip. Nights are sleepless and days restless, and we need an extra boost to keep us going.

headline: S&P 500 briefly falls into bear market territory as recession fears mount

A reversal late in the day pushed the index higher at the market’s close and saved it from reaching an official bear market designation.

headline: Why the looming bear market will be different
body: When a bear market arrives, it’s not pretty, especially for investors making short-term decisions. But it happens — and a recovery arrives eventually.

headline: Worst may not be over for the market. Stocks fall again
body: The 2022 stock market meltdown may not be over just yet. Stocks fell again Thursday, following Wednesday’s massive sell-off.

headline: Plunging stocks, recession fears. Here’s how to protect your money
Melvin Capital to shut after heavy losses on meme stocks, market slump
body: Melvin Capital, once one of Wall Street’s most successful hedge funds which then lost billions in the meme stock saga, will shut down after it was hit again by this year’s market slump.

headline: Global markets slide after a tough day on Wall Street
body: Asian markets mostly closed lower and European indexes slid in early trade on Thursday, continuing Wall Street’s downward spiral hours earlier.

headline: Want to make money in stocks this year? You’ll probably have to sell your soul
body: People are selling stocks, selling bonds, selling crypto, selling their failed hedge funds … and putting cash in Under the Mattress Savings and Loan Corp.

headline: Retailers just sounded an alarm on inflation. It’s worth heeding

headline: Mortgage rates ticked lower, but are still well above 5%
body: Mortgage rates dropped slightly last week, but purchasing a home remains difficult for many prospective buyers.

headline: Dow tumbles 1,160 points in worst trading day since June 2020
body: The old joke goes like this: Two friends are at a resort and one says, “The food here is really terrible.” The other replies, “And the portions are so small!” Today, it’s investors who dislike the taste of the Federal Reserve’s interest rate hikes — but seemingly want more anyway.

headline: S&P 500’s ESG index boots Tesla
body: The S&P 500 index devoted to highlighting companies excelling at ESG, which stands for environmental, social and governance issues, has removed Tesla from the index, it explained in a blog post published on Tuesday. The move comes in the wake of allegations of racial discrimination and poor working conditions at Tesla’s main American factory, as well as safety investigations into its technology.

headline: World’s largest aircraft owner lost 113 planes to Russia due to sanctions
body: AerCap Holdings, the aircraft leasing giant that is the world’s largest owner of jets, lost 113 planes when Russia seized them in response to sanctions triggered by the war in Ukraine.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway finally bails on Wells Fargo
body: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway has been a top investor in Wells Fargo for the past few years, despite the company’s fake account scandal, overcharging foreign-exchange customers and myriad other problems.

headline: $5 gas could become widespread as prices hit another record
body: Prices at the pump continue to shatter records ahead of Memorial Day weekend.

headline: Stocks could fall a lot further

headline: The pandemic-era rally is now a distant memory for some stocks

headline: Top dealmaker says Chinese markets are ‘close to the bottom’
body: One of China’s top investment bankers says the country’s stock markets appear to be nearing “the bottom.”

headline: Novak Djokovic wins 1,000th ATP Tour match with victory in Italian Open semifinal

headline: More than $7 trillion has been wiped out from the stock market this year

It’s a good wager, thanks to the spike in oil prices from about $75 a barrel at the end of last year to above $100 now. Nearly all of the top performers in the S&P 500 this year are energy stocks.

headline: A financial transaction tax may be aimed at hurting Wall Street. But it will hit Main Street investors instead
body: In the wake of the GameStop stock trading frenzy, the Biden administration recently said it’s worth evaluating the impact of a tax on financial transactions, which would include the purchases and sales of stocks, bonds and derivative contracts, such as options and futures. Some claim such a tax could stabilize markets and raise revenue. They say it’s a simple and easy way to raise billions of dollars at the expense of Wall Street and the wealthy. However, history suggests that a financial transaction tax will not raise anywhere near the amount of funds its proponents suggest. And what money it does raise will largely come from Main Street investors, even as it also raises the cost of capital for American corporations.

headline: The stock market is eerily calm again. Uh-oh…
body: A version of this story first appeared in CNN Business’ Before the Bell newsletter. Not a subscriber? You can sign up right here.

headline: Asian stocks recover from losses sparked by the coronavirus outbreak
body: Stocks in Asia recovered a little ground Wednesday after a new virus originating in China drove markets into the red earlier this week and disrupted plans for the millions of people traveling over the Lunar New Year.

headline: Dow tumbles on the first case of coronavirus in the United States
body: The Dow and broader stock market closed in the red Tuesday as reports of the first case of the Wuhan coronavirus in the United States weighed on the market.

headline: Boom and bust: Economy and impeachment capture the forces that will determine Trump’s fate
body: The House officially delivered to the Senate two articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump last week on the same day that the Dow Jones Industrial Average finished above 29,000 points for the first time.

headline: IBM must show restless investors that its cloud strategy is working
body: IBM is one of the most iconic American technology companies. Wall Street no longer views Big Blue as an innovator in a tech landscape  dominated by Amazon, Apple and Google owner Alphabet.

headline: Pharmaceutical stocks spike after China reports new coronavirus cases
body: Chinese pharmaceutical stocks skyrocketed Monday as China reported more than 100 new cases of pneumonia caused by a new strain of coronavirus.

headline: The market’s earnings losing streak may be about to end
body: Earnings season is off to a strong start so far. If the trend continues, then Corporate America may break its streak of three consecutive quarters where profits dropped year-over-year – a phenomenon that’s been dubbed an earnings recession.

headline: The club of $1 trillion companies just keeps growing. Now there are four
body: A version of this story first appeared in CNN Business’ Before the Bell newsletter. Not a subscriber? You can sign up right here.

headline: Google owner Alphabet is now worth $1 trillion
body: The exclusive $1 trillion club on Wall Street just got a new member. Shares of Google parent company Alphabet hit a new all-time high Thursday, pushing the company’s market value to $1 trillion in the process.

headline: Grab your passports. Time to look overseas for stocks
What’s moving markets today: January 15, 2020
body: Here’s what investors are paying attention to.

headline: Larry Ellison has made $1.6 billion on his Tesla stock since joining its board
body: Larry Ellison’s first year on the Tesla board has been very, very profitable.

headline: This could be biggest year for bank mergers since the late 1990s
body: Truist, the financial services giant created from the merger of Southeastern regional banks SunTrust and BB&T, just unveiled a brand new purple logo. There could be many other regional banks that may need new names and brand images this year too.

headline: America’s banks kick off earnings season with a bang
body: A version of this story first appeared in CNN Business’ Before the Bell newsletter. Not a subscriber? You can sign up right here.

headline: How to stay invested if you’re a worrier
body: There are a lot of things to be nervous about. Iran. Still, stocks remain near all-time highs. It’s probably a mistake to get too worried and take your money out of the market. So what’s a conservative long-term investor to do?

headline: Defense and cybersecurity stocks have gotten a boost from US-Iran tension. Can they hold onto their gains?
body: A version of this story first appeared in CNN Business’ Before the Bell newsletter. Not a subscriber? You can sign up right here.

headline: Dow hits a new record: 29,000 points
body: The Dow rose around 40 points to cross the 29,000 level for the first time, but couldn’t sustain its gains and ended the day down 133 points, or 0.5%.

headline: Dow 29,000? US jobs report could give stocks another boost
body: A version of this story first appeared in CNN Business’ Before the Bell newsletter. Not a subscriber? You can sign up right here.

headline: Investors are feeling a lot calmer today about the United States and Iran
body: Markets are continuing to climb after US President Donald Trump allayed investor worries over further escalation of tensions between the United States and Iran.

headline: Stocks tumble after Iran attacks bases housing US troops in Iraq
body: Stocks tumbled Wednesday after Iran launched more than a dozen ballistic missiles at two Iraqi military bases that house US forces.

headline: Aston Martin’s troubles mount as profits slump by 45%
body: Aston Martin stunned investors Tuesday by warning that its profit for 2019 would drop by about 45% despite healthy orders for its first ever SUV.

headline: How Millennials can invest with elite money managers – without breaking the bank
body: Robinhood brought free trading to the masses. Betterment and Wealthfront automated financial advice for millions. Now, Round is seeking to level the investing playing field even further, by admitting Millennials to the exclusive club of elite money managers.

headline: 4 tech companies are worth about $1 trillion. Here’s the best long term bet
body: Apple and Microsoft are each worth more than $1 trillion. Google’s parent company, Alphabet, and Amazon are nearing that level as well. Google even hit a new all-time high on Monday.

headline: Dow tumbles more than 200 points on rising Iran tensions
body: The Dow and US stocks fell Friday after the United States killed a top Iranian commander at a Baghdad airport.

headline: The stock market is on fire. History shows that won’t last
body: The melt-up on Wall Street has reached historic proportions.

headline: The Dow kicks off the new year with a record high
body: US stocks kicked the new decade off with fresh all-time highs.

headline: Shanghai stocks pop on first day of trading in 2020
body: Markets in Shanghai and Hong Kong rose Thursday after China announced that it will take more action to bolster its slowing economy.

headline: Jeff Bezos is still the richest person in the world
body: He topped the Bloomberg Billionaire Index on the final day of 2019.
